title: MTA acknowledges existence of Byford resignation letter, says it’s been withdrawn
text:
"I'm not going anywhere and I remain laser focused on improving day-to-day service for millions of New Yorkers and delivering a transformed transit network,” Byford said. | Flickr MTA acknowledges existence of Byford resignation letter, says it’s been withdrawn

Transit chief Andy Byford has withdrawn the resignation letter he submitted last week — a move the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced hours after POLITICO first reported on the letter’s existence.

“The letter has been rescinded,” MTA spokesperson Abbey Collins said at 3:24 Friday afternoon. She did not comment when asked at what time Byford had withdrawn the letter. The MTA had declined to affirm the existence of the letter earlier in the day.

Story Continued Below

Byford had no immediate comment.

Byford resigned last week, after growing concerned about the prospect of having to oversee potential service cuts and layoffs, at the same time Gov. Andrew Cuomo was putting additional pressures on the MTA’s operating budget.

He also tired of having to spend time helping set up various tech-related conferences for the governor, which were a distraction from his day job running New York City’s subway and bus system.

"I'm not going anywhere and I remain laser focused on improving day-to-day service for millions of New Yorkers and delivering a transformed transit network,” Byford said in a statement released by the MTA press shop on Friday. “The historic $51 billion capital plan provides a golden opportunity to further transform the subway and bus network — with unprecedented investments in accessibility — and my team and I are totally focused on achieving that. The Governor and I are on exactly the same page about the need to dramatically improve the transit system in New York and we now have the plan and the funding to do that."
description: Byford resigned last week, after growing concerned about the prospect of having to oversee potential service cuts and layoffs.
